oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John O. Amstuz (1893 - 1964)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Amstuz (1893 - 1964) was chairman of the board of Hudson Valley Community College during the building of its new campus. He was in the forefront of the long legal battle to receive approval of the new campus. In 1957 a taxpayers group opposed the county participation in the construction. The issue was settled in 1958 when the state court of appeals ruled in the college’s favor. He was the first deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Commerce, vice president and director of the Behr-Manning Corporation and regarded as a leading Troy businessman. He was also a trustee of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and member of the Greater Troy Chamber of Commerce. Building B was renamed the Amstuz Science Hall in the late 1960s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Raymond H. Siek (1912 - 1978)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Raymond Siek was a trustee of Hudson Valley Community College. He was plant manager of the Ford Motor Company of Green Island and served as Rensselaer County Republican Party Chairman for several years. He was the area vice president of Boy Scouts of America, trustee of Russell Sage College and a director of Marine Midland Bank. Along with other members of HVCC’s governing past, he was a member of the Greater Troy Chamber of Commerce, serving as president and chairman. Originally dedicated in 1973 as part of Hudson Valley Community College’s 20th anniversary, the Campus Center was named in memory of Raymond H. Siek in 1979. The college re-dedicated the building in 2006, after completion of an extensive, $8 million renovation project.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James J. Fitzgibbons (1915 -2005)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Fitzgibbons (1915 - 2005) joined in the establishment of the Troy Veteran’s Vocational Institute, which later became Hudson Valley Technical Institute, and evolved to present day Hudson Valley Community College. Mr. Fitzgibbons was HVCC’s second president presiding over the growth of the college throughout the 1960s until 1979. A commissioned officer in the Naval Reserves during World War II, he performed advanced research at MIT and Bowdoin College and was instrumental in the development of the Navy’s Long Range Aid to Navigation. After retiring from HVCC he served as advisor and counsel to the SUNY system and was appointed as interim president of Nassau Community College in the early 1980s. The Fitzgibbons Health Technologies Center was dedicated to James Fitzgibbons after its construction in 1982.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hyman Rosenblum (1911 - 1996)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hyman Rosenblum (1911 - 1996) was one of the founders of HVCC and was instrumental in persuading Rensselaer county officials that a community college was in the best interest of residents and worth their tax dollars. Mr. Rosenblum was on the Board of Trustees from 1953 to 1957 and then became the boards secretary in 1957 and held the position until 1996. He is credited with the proposal to rename the growing institution as Hudson Valley Community College. Mr. Rosenblum was a local pioneer in radio broadcasting and the emerging television field. In 1946, he formed the Hudson Valley Broadcasting Corporation which later became the radio station WROW (the R is for Rosenblum) and established WTEN-TV before selling it to Capital Cities Communications. The Hy Rosenblum Administration Center was dedicated in 1984.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joseph J. Bulmer (1929 - 2006)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Dr. Bulmer (1929 - 2006) was employed by the Knolls Atomic Power Laborary as a nuclear engineer and managed over 2,500 civilian and naval personnel from 1962 to 1979, when he was appointed President of HVCC. He was also involved in many local business and community organizations including the Governor’s Excelsior Committee, College of Saint Rose Board of Directors, President of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Troy Area, Samaritan and St. Mary’s Hospital Boards of Directors, and vice chairman of the American Nuclear Society. Dr. Bulmer served as college president from 1979 until his retirement in 1996. He later served as interim president for Sullivan, Onondaga, Fulton-Montgomery and Clinton County Community Colleges. The Bulmer Telecommunications Center was built in 1995.

For further information: Hudson Valley Remembers Dr. Bulmer (October 2006): Reflections on a Leader - the Legacy of Dr. Joseph J. Bulmer by Dr. Lucille A. Marion. https://www.hvcc.edu/about/bulmer-legacy.pdf

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Conrad H. Lang, Sr. (1906 - 2005)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mr. Lang (1906 - 2005) began his career in the New York State Department of Public Works as a civil engineer. Later, he was appointed Deputy Chief Engineer of the newly created New York State Thruway Authority with the responsibility of supervising the construction and maintenance of the superhighway. In 1969, he was appointed Assistant Commissioner of Operations for the New York State Department of Transportation and supervised the maintenance of the state’s highway and canal system. Mr. Lang served as member and president of the Country Club of Troy; member of the Board of Trustees of Emma Willard School; and a member and president of the American Society of Civil Engineers. He was a charter member of the Board of Trustees of Hudson Valley Community College, serving from 1953 to 1976 including chairman from 1973 to 1976. Building C, built in 1961, was renamed the Lang Technical Building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James M. Brahan (1893 - 1978)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Mr. Brahan (1893 - 1978) was the Rensselaer County Treasurer for seven terms of office, representing the longest tenure in the history of Rensselaer County. He was also publisher of the Hoosick Falls Standard Press. Mr. Brahan was Past President and director of the New York Press Association and a member of the Sigma Delta Chi Syracuse Professional Chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists. During World War II, he was a commissioned officer in the National Guard as a captain, then promoted to major and first battalion commander which included military units in Troy, Cohoes and Hoosick Falls. Mr. Brahan was a charter member of the Board of Trustees and served from 1953 to 1974. Built in 1965, Building F became Brahan Hall in 1966.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lester C. Higbee (1889 - 1974)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mr. Higbee (1889 - 1974) was President and Chairman of the Board of W. & L.E. Gurly Company, a Troy-based producer of measuring instrumentation. He was president and honorary board chairman of the Rensselaer County Chapter of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers. During World War II, Mr. Higbee commanded the upstate area New York State Guard with the final rank of Brigadier-General. Mr. Higbee was a charter member of the HVCC Board of Trustees from 1953 to 1973 and served as president and later as Chairman from 1964 to 1973. Building D was renamed Higbee Hall.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dwight Marvin (1880 - 1972)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Mr. Marvin (1880 - 1972) served as editor of both The Troy Record and Times Record and served as chairman of the board of The Record Newspapers, Inc. He also served as president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in 1941. He held many leadership positions within organizations in the Troy area. Mr. Marvin was the first chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Hudson Valley Technical Institute, later renamed Hudson Valley Community College, and served as a trustee from 1953 to 1961. The Dwight Marvin Library opened on May 23, 1970. A dedication plaque at the library entrance reads “The Dwight Marvin Library – Dedicated to the founding chairman of the Board of Trustees, 1953-1960, Dwight Marvin, in recognition of his unceasing efforts toward the establishment of this college and of his devoted service during the early years of its development.”

A more detailed description of his life can be found:
https://www.hvcc.edu/lrc/dwight-marvin.html

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Otto V. Guenther - older (1897 - 1969)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Otto Guenther (1897 - 1969) was the first president of HVCC as it grew from 88 students to thousands. Before his presidency, Mr. Guenther served as consultant to three other community colleges: Orange County Community College, Jamestown Community College and Berkshire Community College. He also served as chairman of the mechanical and metallurgical technology department at the Erie County Technical Institute in Buffalo. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Greater Troy Chamber of Commerce and a director of the Boy Scouts of America. Building A was constructed in 1961 and became Guenther Hall in the late 1960s. It then was extensively renovated in 2000-2001 and was renamed Guenther Enrollment Services Center.
